Author: Xabier Bello
Version: 0.2.6

Indexing vs iterating

Given a Fasta file, 1.3 Gb in size, with ~40000 sequences and 30 kb per sequence, do the following operations compiled with -d:danger and timing with /usr/bin/time -v:

OperationTimeMemory
newIndex("yourFasta.fas")1.90 s~6000 kbytes
Index + search 1 known sequences...
... at beginning of the file2.04 s~6000 kbytes
... at the middle2.10 s"
... at the end2.07 s"
Index + search 100 random sequences2.08 s~6500 kbytes
Index + search all sequences4.80 s~6500 kbytes
Load pre-saved Index...
... and search 1 known sequence0.02 s~15000 kbytes
... and search 100 random sequences0.03 s"
Iterate through all sequences2.45 s~4200 kbytes

Random sequence extraction

You can get partial sequences using the [] procedures in this module. But if you plan to use a lot of querying on huge chromosomes, maybe you should try hts-nim. The feature is a bit hidden but here you have a sample (needs an index of the fasta file):

import hts

var faidx: Fai

doAssert f.open("UCSC.hg19.fasta")
echo f.get("chr1:100000-100100")

# Or

echo f.get("chr1", 100000, 100100)

That is about 100x faster and uses 100x less memory than the equivalent bio code.

Imports

sequences

Types

FileType = enum
  ftFasta = "fasta"
The filetype, to allow potential future filetypes handling. 
Index = ref object of RootObj
  source*: string
  table*: TableRef[string, int64]
The index is a table with the name of the sequence as a string, except the initial '>', and its position in the file. The filename which the Index refers to is stored in source.

Procs

proc newIndex(fName: string): Index {...}{.raises: [IOError], tags: [ReadIOEffect].}

Build an Index for a given fasta file.

You should build an index if you plan to access a few sequences by name randomly and repeatedly. If you'll need all the sequences and specially if you only need it once, use sequences iterator

import bio/fasta

let index: Index = newIndex("path/to/file.fas")

Once created, saving and loading of Indexes is covered in a recipe. 

proc `[]`(index: Index; fileIn: File; name: string): SequenceRecord {...}{.inline,
    raises: [IOError, KeyError, EOFError], tags: [ReadIOEffect].}

Returns a SequenceRecord from an Index using an already opened file handler.

Ignores the file path provided with Index.source field, and doesn't check the validity of fileIn handler (e.g. if it's in fmRead mode).

import bio/fasta

let index: Index = newIndex("path/to/file.fas")

block:
  let fastaFile = open("path/to/file.fas")
  defer: fastaFile.close
  echo index[fastaFile, "My Record"]
  echo index[fastaFile, "Other Record"]
proc `[]`(index: Index; name: string): SequenceRecord {...}{.inline,
    raises: [IOError, KeyError, EOFError], tags: [ReadIOEffect].}

Returns a SequenceRecords from an Index.

Doesn't check if the file provided at Index.source exists, and open/closes it on each access.

import bio/fasta

let index: Index = newIndex("path/to/file.fas")
echo index["My Record"]
proc `$`(index: Index): string {...}{.inline, raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}
Returns a brief description of the Index.
import bio/fasta

let index: Index = newIndex("path/to/file.fas")
echo index
> Index for path/to/file.fas, length: 232
proc load(fName: string; kind: FileType = ftFasta): seq[SequenceRecord] {...}{.
    raises: [IOError, OSError], tags: [ReadIOEffect].}

Load a seq of SequenceRecords from a filename.

Careful: this loads all the file at once. If you need an interator over the file, use the sequences iterator

import bio/fasta

let mySeqs = load("path/to/file.fas")
proc dumpTo(record: SequenceRecord; fHandler: File; kind: FileType = ftFasta) {...}{.
    raises: [IOError], tags: [WriteIOEffect].}

Write a SequenceRecords to fHandler, wrapping the sequence by 60 positions. The name of the SequenceRecord remains untouched.

TBD: kind is a string as in "fasta", to support different formats. Right now only FASTA files are supported.

To write a FASTA file myOutput.fasta with the contents:

`import bio/fasta`

let mySeq = newDna("TGCACCCCA")
let myRec = SequenceRecord(name: "My DNA sequence", record: mySeq)

block:
  let fastaOut = open("myOutput.fasta", fmWrite)
  defer: fastaOut.close
  myRec.dumpTo(fastaOut)
proc dumpTo(records: seq[SequenceRecord]; fHandler: File;
            kind: FileType = ftFasta) {...}{.raises: [IOError], tags: [WriteIOEffect].}
A shortcut to avoid the explicit cycle to write a seq of SequenceRecords
import bio/fasta

let mySeqA = newDna("TGCACCCCA")
let mySeqB = newDna("GTGAGAGTG")
let myRecA = SequenceRecord(name: "My DNA sequence", record: mySeqA)
let myRecB = SequenceRecord(name: "My DNA sequence", record: mySeqB)

block:
  let fastaOut = open("myOutput.fasta", fmWrite)
  defer: fastaOut.close
  @[myRecA, myRecB].dumpTo(fastaOut)
proc dumpTo(record: SequenceRecord; fName: string; kind: FileType = ftFasta) {...}{.
    raises: [IOError], tags: [WriteIOEffect].}

Same as write-through-handler proc but you only need to point out the name of the file.

If the file exists, it will be silently overwritten.

import bio/fasta

let mySeq = newDna("TGCACCCCA")
let myRec = SequenceRecord(name: "My DNA sequence", record: mySeq)

myRec.dumpTo("myOutput.fasta")
proc dumpTo(records: seq[SequenceRecord]; fName: string;
            kind: FileType = ftFasta) {...}{.raises: [IOError], tags: [WriteIOEffect].}

Same as write-through-handler proc but you only need to point out the name of the file.

If the file exists, it will be silently overwritten.

import bio/fasta

let mySeqA = newDna("TGCACCCCA")
let mySeqB = newDna("GTGAGAGTG")
let myRecA = SequenceRecord(name: "My DNA sequence", record: mySeqA)
let myRecB = SequenceRecord(name: "My DNA sequence", record: mySeqB)

myRecs = @[myRecA, myRecB]
myRecs.dumpTo("myOutput.fasta")

Iterators

iterator sequences(strm: Stream; kind: FileType = ftFasta): SequenceRecord {...}{.
    inline, raises: [IOError, OSError], tags: [ReadIOEffect].}
Iterate through all the Sequences in a given stream, yielding SequenceRecords.
import streams
import bio/fasta

var strm = newFileStream("path/to/file.fas")

for sequence in sequences(strm):
  doAssert(sequence of SequenceRecord)

Reading Streams allows you to consume compressed files directly, e.g.:

import zip/gzipfiles # Requires https://github.com/nim-lang/zip

import streams
import bio/fasta

var strm = newGzFileStream("path/to/file.fas.gz")

for sequence in sequences(strm):
  doAssert(sequence of SequenceRecord)
iterator sequences(data: seq[string]; kind: FileType = ftFasta): SequenceRecord {...}{.
    inline, raises: [IOError, OSError], tags: [ReadIOEffect].}

Iterate through all the Sequences in a given sequence of strings, yielding SequenceRecords.

I found this useful only to embed a sequence in a program.

import bio/fasta

const data = slurp("path/to/file.fas").splitLines

for sequence in sequences(data):
  doAssert(sequence of SequenceRecord)
iterator sequences(fName: string; kind: FileType = ftFasta): SequenceRecord {...}{.
    inline, raises: [IOError, OSError], tags: [ReadIOEffect].}
Iterate through all the Sequences in a given filename, yielding SequenceRecords.
import bio/fasta

for sequence in sequences("path/to/file.fas"):
  doAssert(sequence of SequenceRecord)
iterator items(index: Index): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}

Iterate through all the Index items, yielding the names of the sequences in the index.

If you need the actual SequenceRecords, use the [] getters. If you need the positions of each SequenceRecord in file, access the underlying Table directly (you have to import tables to do it).

import bio/fasta

let index: Index = newIndex("path/to/file.fas")

for sequenceName in index:
  echo sequenceName
  echo index[sequenceName]
